Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion. BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2014-2018 Strategic Plan, namely to "integrate education and research to support development of a diverse STEM workforce with cutting-edge capabilities." The vision of this grant is to provide a national model for the production of underrepresented scientists and engineers with doctoral degrees in STEM.

Louisiana State University (LSU) serves as host of a Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) project within the Louis Stokes - Louisiana Alliance for Minority Participation. The LSU BD activity employs a multifaceted model that integrates research, education, and mentoring to address challenges underrepresented students face in doctoral programs. As such this project seeks to (1) recruit a cohort of twelve highly qualified Fellows from underrepresented racial and ethnic backgrounds employing evidence-based recruitment and selection strategies; (2) retain and support Fellows through doctoral candidacy, and prepare them for successful completion of the PhD and professional research careers by providing academic and research support, and professional development opportunities; and (3) expand and institutionalize best mentoring strategies for underrepresented PhD students. The program components are executed via an educational model that integrates mentoring and research into recruitment and retention strategies. This proposal implements additional requirements that BD Fellows apply for the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP). Toward this end, scientific communication, especially written communication, will become a larger focus for this cohort. The use of Individual Development Plans (IDPs) will be refined and a new Bridge Orientation will be implemented. Evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies will be employed. The proposal includes a transformative design that incorporates inter- and intra-institutional alliances to improve the quality of STEM education at the doctoral level. This project will implement evidence-based mentoring strategies designed to support student matriculation and tools to promote self-efficacy toward PhD candidacy and doctoral attainment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

“LS-LAMP/BD-Cohort 8 – LA-BRIDGE: Louisiana Broadening Resources for Increasing Diversity in Graduate Education,” at Louisiana State University (referred to herein as LA-BRIDGE) and its related activities represent a transformative and strategic institutional approach to build human resource capital at the doctoral level.  

LA-BRIDGE has four main programmatic components: (1) Systemic mentoring program to provide infrastructure for students to integrate into the university culture; (2) Academic support structure that prepares students for the rigors of doctoral study; (3) National research experiences that incentivize early success and prepare students for life-long engagement in the global STEM research enterprise; and (4) Individual Development Plans (IDPs) to enable self-efficacy and support student success. 

Summary of Project Impacts: Through BD activities, LSU has experienced a dramatic increase in the overall diversity of its STEM doctoral programs. Before LS-LAMP BD, the minority STEM PhD student population campus-wide leveled off with a critical mass of approximately 40 students, about 70% of which were housed with the chemistry department. Notably, LSU has and maintains a reputation for being a top producer of African American PhDs in chemistry. The mentoring efforts of its faculty, particularly professor Isiah M. Warner, have been recognized for not only increasing minority student matriculation but also mentoring to increase retention to graduation. 

Via NSF BD support, and working closely with the LS-LAMP partners, the PIs of the prior LS-LAMP BD activities have been able to expand the success in chemistry to other LSU departments and divisions. With BD support, LSU was able to double its minority STEM doctoral student population to nearly 80 students and sustain this over multiple years. Notably, the minority student population in chemistry has leveled off and the net increases have been realized as a direct result of increased minority student matriculation and retention within campus-wide STEM doctoral programs. 

Greater than 75% of minority PhDs at LSU have been supported by mentoring programs housed within the LSU Office of Strategic Initiatives, and the BD program has been the cornerstone of OSI’s mentoring efforts for STEM doctoral students by supporting 116 students since inception. 

Programmatic Components

The 12 recruited LA-BRIDGE Fellows were immersed in a systemic mentoring environment. 

Specifically, in addition to being fully supported financially, these fellows are in individualized mentoring relationships with their advisors in the respective departments as well as BD leadership. They attend monthly research and enhancement seminars of the BD program as well as additional discipline-specific research seminars in their units. Further the current cohort engaged in outreach designed by OSI and other LSU units to further integrate students to campus. Their academic and professional integration includes their research participation and their attendance at national, professional conferences. LSU is committed to supporting the current BD cohort beyond their two-year tenure in the BD program. 

The 12 maintained LA-BRIDGE (BD-8) Fellows were engaged in systemic mentoring (i.e., woven into the instructional, research, and service fabric of the institution) central to LS-LAMP-BD and provided a seamless pathway for success at the PhD level. Specific programmatic activities included (1) a systemic mentoring program that included effective faculty-to-student and student-to-student interactions that work collaboratively to increase the number of minority students earning PhD degrees in STEM fields; (2) academic support structures that increase students’ acclimations to the rigors of doctoral study; and (3) minority students exposure to international research opportunities that prepare them for long-term scholarly engagement in the global STEM research enterprise. 

In addition to presenting their research and attending technical seminars, the scholars were expected to attend LAMP-BD seminars on a variety of topics that demystify doctorate and postdoctoral programs, help them thrive in graduate school, and provide insight into the intricacies of the global STEM workforce enterprise, with the focus on the professoriate. It is important to note that the seminars and activities planned for the spring semester were highly effected by COVID-19, and as a result, we were forced to switch to a virtual platform. To our surprise, the switch to a virtual environment did not cause many lapses in programming for fellows. All fellows, depending on the year, were engaged in two summer workshops to support writing activities. Students who had not applied for the NSF GRFP were involved in a two-month Fellowship Bootcamp that thoroughly investigated fellowships with a focus on the GRFP and each component. Those who had applied to the GRFP the year before engaged in a 6-week intense writing course to help them understand how to structure proposals and general exams for academic success. When students were asked how they felt COVID-19 impacted their experience as a graduate student, all fellows expressed if it had not been for the LSU Bridge to Doctorate Program and monthly one-on-one coaching/mentoring sessions the transition would have been awful. All fellows felt prepared to handle the remaining time in graduate school.
